cons: There’s a lot of work to be done.

job_title: Family Preservation Specialist in Brookville, IN
pros:
My boss - BobbiJo Short - was very helpful, always available when needed - provided excellent leadership skills, not just for me as an individual, but for our whole team.

My team - excellent people to work with. They were always ready to help and assist when needed. A whole lot of fun to hang with after hours. 

Excellent PTO

Decent pay
cons: The paperwork required for the job, required by the state, was a bit too much!

review_title: Love helping, pay for MH clinician's is approx $9000 below average
pros: Supportive co-workers, autonomy driven environment, generous amount of paid holidays, and vacation. 401K match, health, dental, vision, life, disability, and accident insurance is available. Paid training classes and supplies. Helping others.
cons: Pay is approx $9000 below average for the 30 mile vicinity. Turnover is high in the MH department due to the low pay, high stress, and pressure to carry a large caseload. People in other departments do not really understand what mental health clinicians really do, the amount of indirect work required for each patient along with the large caseloads is almost unmanageable. Mental health documentation was an afterthought on the platform we use, it is slow, there are too many choices to sort through and too many mouse clicks, after each click 4-5 seconds minimum to load, and this only serves to drag out the time it takes to enter documentation , Other non-clinicians have much more downtime and it is common for some of them to sit and chat with co-workers, for hours, or be on their phone, or shop online while the rest of us are slammed with work. Some co-workers are out of the office sick a lot and oftentimes we don't know about it until we try to find that person. Some co-workers do not respect boundaries, nor the fact that MH clinician's have strict ethics/laws/HIPPA that we must follow or risk losing our licenses. Admin staff is not trained at all on anything other than the phones, which is a huge liability, and the MH dept does not have time to train people who have never worked in the MH/medical field. We are told we have to work our full 40 hours, although we are salary, yet others often leave for lunch and leave early. Clickish at times, and MH workers often are out of the loop because our workload is so high we don't have time to sit around and talk.

pros: A big pro is they have great people in administration!
cons: The mental health industry is lower paying in general, so that would be the biggest con.

pros: Lots of ways to explore what population and what skills you'd like to use

cons: Low pay and long hours . Lots of paperwork .
